results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response: The answer is:
results.json_rows_response:
1. The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined with reference to quoted market prices at the end of the reporting period. A market is regarded as active if quoted prices are readily and regularly available from an exchange, dealer, broker, industry group, pricing service, or regulatory agency, and those prices represent actual and regularly occurring market transactions on an arm’s length basis.
2. A market is regarded as active if the fair value of a financial instrument is determined with reference to observable market data, where the data is available and is reflected in the price at the end of the reporting period.
3. A market is regarded as active if the fair value of a financial instrument is determined with reference to observable market data, where the data is not available and is reflected in the price at the end of the reporting period.
4. The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined with reference to quoted market prices at the end of the reporting period. A market is regarded as active if quoted prices are readily and regularly available from an exchange, dealer, broker, industry group, pricing service, or regulatory agency, and those prices represent actual and regularly occurring market transactions on an arm’s length basis.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?

Net loss per share is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.

results.question: What led to lower capital expenditures at Bell Media in 2019?

• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital expenditures in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

• The year-over-year increase in our wireless segment of 0.3 pts in 2019 compared to 2018 was primarily due to the ongoing construction of our LTE-A network and the progress made in the roll-out of our LTE-A small-cells.
• The year-over-year increase in our wireline segment of 0.3 pts in 2019 compared to 2018 was primarily due to the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts.
• The year-over-year reduction in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019 compared to 2018 was primarily due to our focus on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses and the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts.

results.markdown_table_response:
Sales: CTS sales increased 27% to $849.8 million in 2019 compared to $670.7 million in 2018, including the impact of the adoption of ASC 606. The increase in sales was primarily driven by growth in both organic and inorganic business in North America. Sales in 2019 were higher in the U.S. primarily due to system development on contracts in New York, Boston, and the San Francisco Bay Area. Businesses acquired by CTS during fiscal year 2019, whose operations are all located in the U.S., had sales of $74.4 million in fiscal year 2019. Sales were higher in Australia between fiscal years 2018 and 2019 as increased system development work on a contract in Brisbane was partially offset by the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates as well as a decrease in service sales. Sales were lower in the UK primarily due to a decrease in system development work in London and the negative impact of currency exchange rates. The average exchange rates between the prevailing currencies in our foreign operations and the U.S. dollar resulted in a decrease in CTS sales of $22.2 million for 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the British pound and Australian dollar.

results.question: Which locations are responsible for driving the increase in sales in 2019?
results.markdown_table_response:
AT&T
Sales: AT&T sales increased 28% to $8,216.2 million in 2019 compared to $6,480.9 million in 2018, including the impact of the adoption of ASC 606. The increase in sales was primarily driven by growth in both organic and inorganic business in North America. Sales in 2019 were higher in the U.S. primarily due to system development work on contracts in New York, Boston, and the San Francisco Bay Area. Businesses acquired by AT&T during fiscal year 2019, whose operations are all located in the U.S., had sales of $6.2 million in fiscal year 2019. Sales increased slightly in Australia between fiscal years 2018 and 2019 as increased system development work on a contract in Brisbane was partially offset by the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates as well as a decrease in service sales. Sales were lower in the UK primarily due to a decrease in system development work in London and the negative impact of currency exchange rates. The average exchange rates between the prevailing currencies in our foreign operations and the U.S. dollar resulted in a decrease in AT&T sales of $23.9 million for 2019 compared to 2018, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the British pound
